scenario: A mother brings her 7-year-old son to the clinic with a facial rash that started four days ago as a small red spot by his nose. It has now spread to the area around his mouth and consists of multiple small vesicles and pustules. Several lesions have ruptured and are covered with a thick, adherent, golden-yellow crust. The mother mentions he often has a runny nose and tends to pick at it. He is otherwise healthy, afebrile, and his immunizations are up to date. He attends a local primary school.

questions.question: The clinical presentation of fragile vesicles and pustules that rupture easily to form a characteristic, thick, 'honey-coloured' crust in a periorificial distribution on a child is highly distinctive. Based on this pathognomonic appearance, what is the most likely clinical diagnosis the Nurse Practitioner should make? Accurate pattern recognition is key to diagnosing common dermatological conditions.

options.description: Herpes Simplex Virus (cold sores), which typically presents with clustered vesicles that crust but are not usually described as 'honey-coloured'.
Non-bullous Impetigo, a superficial bacterial skin infection most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes.
Tinea Faciei (facial ringworm), a fungal infection that usually presents as an annular, scaly patch with central clearing.
Allergic Contact Dermatitis, which would likely present with more diffuse erythema, edema, and intense pruritus.

questions.reference: BCCNM Applying the Competencies for NPs

questions.question: Having diagnosed localized, non-bullous impetigo, the NP must select the most appropriate first-line treatment. According to Canadian Paediatric Society recommendations and principles of antimicrobial stewardship, what is the preferred management for this specific presentation to ensure efficacy while minimizing systemic side effects and antibiotic resistance?

options.description: A 7-day course of an oral antibiotic, such as cephalexin, to ensure systemic treatment of the infection.
A topical corticosteroid cream, such as hydrocortisone 1%, to reduce the associated inflammation.
Topical antibiotic therapy with mupirocin 2% or fusidic acid 2% ointment applied to the affected areas.
Observation and gentle cleansing with soap and water, as the infection is often self-limiting.

questions.reference: Canadian Paediatric Society - Impetigo: Diagnosis and management

questions.question: You have prescribed topical mupirocin ointment. To ensure the medication can effectively penetrate the site of infection, what crucial instruction must the NP provide to the mother regarding the application of the ointment? This practical advice directly impacts the treatment's success and the speed of resolution by addressing the physical barrier created by the infection.

options.description: Instruct her to apply a very thick layer of the ointment directly over the existing honey-coloured crusts.
Advise her to mix the mupirocin with petroleum jelly to make it easier to spread over a larger area.
Counsel her to gently soak the affected areas with a warm, damp cloth to soften and remove the crusts before applying a thin layer of the ointment to the underlying skin.
Tell her to apply the ointment only around the edges of the rash to prevent it from spreading.

questions.reference: Canadian Paediatric Society - Impetigo: Diagnosis and management

questions.question: The mother is concerned about the infection spreading to her other children and asks when her son can safely return to school. What is the most accurate and appropriate counselling the NP should provide regarding the period of infectivity and school exclusion for impetigo? This advice must balance public health considerations with the child's need to return to his normal activities.

options.description: He can return to school immediately as long as he is afebrile, as the infection is not highly contagious.
He must be kept home from school until all the lesions have completely crusted over and fallen off, which could take one to two weeks.
He may return to school 24 hours after initiating appropriate antibiotic therapy (topical or oral), provided that the weeping lesions can be reliably covered with a bandage.
He needs to complete the full 7-day course of antibiotics before he can be considered non-contagious and return to school.

questions.reference: Canadian Paediatric Society - Impetigo: Diagnosis and management

questions.question: While impetigo is usually a straightforward diagnosis, the NP must remain vigilant for signs of a more severe or complicated infection. Which of the following developing signs or symptoms, if reported by the mother in a follow-up call, would be the most concerning 'red flag' and prompt an immediate reassessment of the child?

options.description: The appearance of one or two new, small lesions near the original site.
Mild itching at the site of the rash, which is a common symptom.
The development of surrounding erythema that is warm, tender, and expanding (suggesting cellulitis), or the child becoming systemically unwell with fever and lethargy.
The mother reporting that the crusts are difficult to remove in the morning.

questions.reference: Blueprint for the Canadian NP Licensure Exam

scenario: A 68-year-old male with a history of well-controlled hypertension and osteoarthritis presents to your primary care clinic. He reports a three-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath, particularly when walking up a flight of stairs. He also has a persistent cough productive of clear sputum, most prominent in the mornings. He is a former smoker with a 40-pack-year history but quit five years ago. On examination, his vital signs are stable, but you note a prolonged expiratory phase and scattered expiratory wheezes on auscultation. His oxygen saturation is 95% on room air.

questions.question: Given this patient's chronic presentation and history, which diagnostic investigation is most crucial to perform next to differentiate between potential underlying respiratory conditions and establish a definitive diagnosis? You are aiming to obtain objective data on airflow limitation which is essential for guiding the subsequent management plan and confirming the clinical suspicion raised by his symptoms and smoking history.

options.description: A six-minute walk test to objectively quantify his functional exercise limitation and desaturation.
A chest X-ray (PA and lateral views) to screen for parenchymal lung disease, cardiomegaly, or other structural abnormalities.
Spirometry with pre- and post-bronchodilator testing to assess for airflow obstruction and its reversibility.
An electrocardiogram (ECG) to rule out a cardiac etiology for his dyspnea, such as undiagnosed ischemic heart disease.

questions.question: The patient's post-bronchodilator spirometry reveals an FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.65 and an FEV1 of 65% of predicted. The chest X-ray shows hyperinflation but no acute infiltrates or significant cardiomegaly. Integrating these findings with his clinical history of progressive dyspnea, chronic productive cough, and significant smoking history, what is the most likely diagnosis that synthesizes all available evidence?

options.description: Late-onset asthma with a fixed airflow obstruction component, given the presence of wheezing.
Congestive heart failure, as his dyspnea on exertion could be secondary to cardiac dysfunction.
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), GOLD Stage 2, based on the irreversible airflow limitation and symptomatology.
Bronchiectasis, considering his chronic productive cough, though this is less likely without a history of recurrent infections.

questions.question: Now that a diagnosis of moderate COPD has been established, what is the most appropriate initial pharmacological agent to prescribe for this patient to manage his daily symptoms and reduce his risk of exacerbations, according to the 2023 Canadian Thoracic Society (CTS) guidelines? The goal is to provide maintenance therapy that addresses both bronchodilation and underlying inflammation effectively for a symptomatic patient with no history of asthma.

options.description: A short-acting beta2-agonist (SABA) like salbutamol, to be used on a scheduled basis four times daily.
An inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) monotherapy, such as fluticasone, to manage airway inflammation.
A long-acting muscarinic antagonist (LAMA) such as tiotropium, as a first-line maintenance bronchodilator.
Oral theophylline, as it provides broad bronchodilator effects and is cost-effective.

questions.question: During your discussion about the new diagnosis of COPD, the patient expresses anxiety about his future and asks, 'Does this mean I'm going to be on oxygen soon?'. What is the most therapeutic and evidence-based counselling approach to address his concern? Your goal is to provide realistic reassurance while empowering him to take an active role in managing his condition and preventing disease progression.

options.description: Reassure him that oxygen is rarely needed and he likely won't have to worry about it in the future.
Focus the conversation on the importance of adherence to his new inhaler to prevent the need for oxygen therapy.

Explain that while oxygen is a possibility if the disease progresses, the most impactful actions he can take now, like continued smoking abstinence and starting pulmonary rehabilitation, can significantly slow the disease and maintain his quality of life.
Provide him with statistical data on the percentage of COPD patients who eventually require long-term oxygen therapy.

questions.subdomain: Transition of Care, Discharge Planning and Documentation
questions.question: You decide to refer the patient to a pulmonary rehabilitation program. Which of the following components is most essential to include in the referral documentation to ensure the receiving team has the necessary information for a safe and effective intake process? The referral should be comprehensive, providing a clear clinical picture and justification for the program.

options.description: A detailed summary of his social history, including his marital status and living arrangements.
A copy of his most recent spirometry report, a summary of his current symptoms, functional limitations, and a list of his current medications.
A note confirming he has quit smoking and is motivated to participate in the program.
Only the formal diagnosis of COPD and the prescribing NP's contact information.

scenario: A 32-year-old female graphic designer presents to your clinic with a three-month history of insidious-onset pain, stiffness, and swelling in her hands and wrists. The symptoms are symmetrical, affecting both wrists and multiple metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. She reports pronounced morning stiffness that lasts for approximately 90 minutes, making it difficult to grip her coffee mug or use her computer mouse. She has tried over-the-counter naproxen with only minimal, temporary relief. She has no other past medical history and takes no regular medications.

questions.question: During the physical examination for this patient, which finding would be most indicative of an inflammatory arthritis, such as Rheumatoid Arthritis, and be most crucial in differentiating it from a more mechanical or degenerative process like osteoarthritis? You are seeking a specific, objective sign that points towards active synovitis, a hallmark of inflammatory joint disease, which would heighten your clinical suspicion.

options.description: Presence of Heberden's nodes on the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints.
A positive Phalen's test, indicating potential carpal tunnel syndrome.
Pain on joint palpation without any visible swelling or erythema.
Palpable, soft, 'boggy' swelling of the MCP and wrist joints, indicating synovial proliferation.

questions.question: To investigate the likely diagnosis of Rheumatoid Arthritis and rule out other potential causes for her polyarthritis, which panel of initial laboratory tests would be the most comprehensive and appropriate to order at this stage? Your goal is to gather baseline inflammatory markers, specific autoantibodies, and rule out common mimics, providing a robust dataset for diagnosis and specialist referral.

options.description: Complete Blood Count (CBC), C-Reactive Protein (CRP), Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR), Rheumatoid Factor (RF), and anti-Cyclic Citrullinated Peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies.
Rheumatoid Factor (RF) only, as it is the most traditional test for Rheumatoid Arthritis.
Anti-Nuclear Antibody (ANA) and a Lyme disease serology test to focus on alternative diagnoses.
Uric acid level, CBC, and a basic metabolic panel to screen for gout and kidney function.

questions.question: While awaiting the results of the laboratory investigations and a rheumatology consultation, which initial management strategy is most appropriate for the Nurse Practitioner to recommend to help manage her symptoms? The aim is to provide safe, preliminary symptom relief and functional improvement without initiating disease-modifying agents, which fall under the specialist's purview according to Canadian practice standards for this condition.

options.description: Initiate a course of oral prednisone 20 mg daily to rapidly suppress inflammation.
Prescribe a scheduled, full-dose nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), such as naproxen 500 mg twice daily with food, and advise on adjunctive therapies like heat/cold application.
Start her on methotrexate 15 mg weekly, as this is the standard of care for Rheumatoid Arthritis.
Advise complete rest of the affected joints and provide wrist splints for continuous wear throughout the day.

questions.question: The patient appears distressed by the potential diagnosis of a chronic illness, stating, 'I'm a graphic designer, my hands are my livelihood. What is this going to do to my career?' How should the NP best respond to counsel the patient, acknowledging her fears while providing accurate information and fostering hope? The response should be empathetic and focus on the current treatment paradigm for inflammatory arthritis.

options.description: Advise her to start considering alternative career options in case her hand function deteriorates significantly.
Reassure her that modern treatments are so effective that she will not experience any impact on her work.

Acknowledge the validity of her concerns and explain that the primary goal of modern 'treat-to-target' strategies is to prevent joint damage and preserve function, often allowing people to continue their careers. Emphasize the importance of early diagnosis and collaboration with the rheumatology team.
Tell her not to worry until a definitive diagnosis is made by the specialist, as it could be something else.

questions.subdomain: Transition of Care, Discharge Planning and Documentation
questions.question: You are preparing the referral to the rheumatologist. According to the BCCNM competencies which classify Rheumatoid Arthritis as a condition requiring consultation (Code C), which statement best reflects the NP's role and the purpose of the referral? The referral should clearly articulate the clinical findings and the specific ask of the consultant, demonstrating appropriate interprofessional collaboration.

options.description: The referral should transfer full responsibility for all aspects of the patient's care to the rheumatologist indefinitely.

The referral should ask the rheumatologist to confirm the diagnosis, recommend a management plan including DMARDs, and clarify the plan for co-management, with the NP continuing to manage the patient's primary care needs.
The referral should state that the NP has diagnosed Rheumatoid Arthritis and is requesting the rheumatologist to prescribe the necessary medications.
The referral should request that the rheumatologist perform a one-time assessment and provide recommendations for the NP to manage independently going forward.

scenario: A 7-year-old boy with a known diagnosis of intermittent asthma is brought to the urgent care clinic by his father. Over the past 48 hours, he has developed a worsening cough and audible wheezing. His father reports that he has been using his salbutamol (Ventolin) inhaler every three hours for the past day with only partial and short-lived relief. In the clinic, the boy is alert but anxious, speaking in short, fragmented sentences. His respiratory rate is 36 breaths/minute, heart rate is 125 bpm, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. You observe supraclavicular retractions and widespread expiratory wheezes on auscultation.

questions.question: Based on the initial presentation of this 7-year-old boy in moderate to severe respiratory distress, which assessment finding is the most critical to obtain immediately to determine the severity of the asthma exacerbation and guide your next action? Your priority is to identify signs of impending respiratory failure, which would necessitate immediate escalation of care beyond the capabilities of a standard clinic setting.

options.description: The exact number of salbutamol puffs he has taken in the last 24 hours.
A detailed history of his previous asthma-related hospitalizations.
Presence of a 'silent chest' (diminished or absent wheezing) despite increased work of breathing.
The date of his last follow-up visit with his regular primary care provider.

questions.question: Given the patient's signs of a severe asthma exacerbation (SpO2 92%, use of accessory muscles, fragmented speech), what is the most appropriate initial sequence of interventions to perform immediately in the clinic, according to GINA guidelines? Your goal is to rapidly reverse bronchoconstriction and reduce airway inflammation while preparing for potential transfer to a higher level of care.

options.description: Administer a single dose of salbutamol by MDI and spacer and reassess in 20 minutes before deciding on further action.
Administer back-to-back nebulized salbutamol and ipratropium bromide, administer oral corticosteroids (e.g., dexamethasone), and apply supplemental oxygen to maintain SpO2 >94%.
Arrange for immediate transport to the emergency department without providing any in-clinic treatment to avoid delaying definitive care.
Prescribe a 5-day course of oral prednisone for the father to start at home and advise continued salbutamol use.

questions.question: After your initial interventions, the boy's condition stabilizes, and he is eventually discharged from the emergency department. He follows up with you two days later. He is currently on a short course of oral prednisolone. To prevent future exacerbations of this severity, what is the most appropriate adjustment to his long-term asthma management plan according to the GINA 2024 guidelines for a child his age with evidence of poor control?

options.description: Continue with as-needed salbutamol reliever therapy only, as this was a single severe event.
Initiate a daily low-dose inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) as a controller medication.
Add a long-acting beta2-agonist (LABA) monotherapy to his regimen.
Recommend a trial of a leukotriene receptor antagonist (e.g., montelukast) as the first-line controller therapy.

questions.question: During the follow-up visit, you provide the father with a written asthma action plan. To ensure he understands how to use it effectively, which counselling technique would best evaluate his comprehension and ability to act appropriately during a future exacerbation? The goal is to move beyond simple instruction to active confirmation of understanding and skill, which is crucial for patient safety in chronic disease management.

options.description: Ask the father to read the entire action plan out loud back to you.
Give him the plan and ask if he has any questions about what is written.
Use the 'teach-back' method by presenting a hypothetical scenario (e.g., 'If your son starts coughing at night, what would you do first based on this plan?') and asking him to explain the steps.
Provide a phone number for a telehealth service he can call if he is unsure what to do in the future.

questions.subdomain: Transition of Care, Discharge Planning and Documentation
questions.question: In the urgent care setting, after providing initial stabilizing treatments, you must decide whether the patient can be safely managed in the community or requires immediate transfer to a hospital emergency department. Which of the following clinical scenarios would most strongly indicate the need for immediate transfer to a higher level of care, representing a failure to respond adequately to initial therapy?

options.description: The patient's respiratory rate decreases from 36 to 30 breaths/minute and his oxygen saturation improves to 95% on room air.
The patient's wheezing is still audible, but he is now speaking in full sentences and his retractions have resolved.
The patient remains drowsy or confused, his oxygen saturation fails to improve above 92% despite supplemental oxygen, and his work of breathing remains high.
The patient's father expresses anxiety about managing the condition at home without further support.

scenario: Mr. Chen, a 58-year-old man with a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes, presents for a scheduled follow-up at your primary care clinic. He is currently treated with metformin 1000 mg twice daily and atorvastatin. His most recent HbA1c, taken last week, was 8.1%. During the review of systems, he reports a new onset of 'pins and needles' and numbness in both feet, which disturbs his sleep. On inspection, you notice he is wearing worn-out slippers. You also identify a 1 cm, round, superficial ulcer with a calloused border on the plantar surface of his right great toe, which he was unaware of. The ulcer base is clean, with no purulence or erythema.

questions.question: To properly stage the newly discovered foot ulcer and assess for co-existing peripheral arterial disease, which combination of physical assessments is most essential for the NP to perform? This comprehensive evaluation is critical to determine the risk of limb-threatening complications and to formulate an appropriate, multi-faceted management plan that addresses both the neurological and vascular components of diabetic foot disease.

options.description: Assessing for pedal edema and measuring the calf circumference of both legs.
Testing only for light touch with a cotton ball and observing skin colour.
Performing a 10-g monofilament test for sensation, assessing pedal pulses (dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial), and calculating the ankle-brachial index (ABI).
Probing the ulcer with a sterile cotton-tipped applicator to assess for tenderness.

questions.question: Mr. Chen's 10-g monofilament test is abnormal (he cannot feel it in 4 out of 10 sites on both feet), and his ABI is 1.1. The ulcer does not probe to bone. Based on the integration of his symptoms (paresthesia), physical exam findings, and history, which set of diagnoses most accurately and completely describes his current clinical status?

options.description: Uncomplicated Type 2 Diabetes with poor glycemic control.
Type 2 Diabetes with symptomatic peripheral neuropathy and a non-infected, neuropathic foot ulcer.
Type 2 Diabetes with critical limb ischemia and an arterial foot ulcer.
Tinea pedis with a secondary skin breakdown, unrelated to his diabetes.

questions.question: Given Mr. Chen's HbA1c of 8.1% despite maximal doses of metformin, and the new presence of microvascular complications (neuropathy and ulcer), what is the most appropriate next step to intensify his glycemic management according to the 2023 Diabetes Canada guidelines? The goal is to choose an agent that not only improves glycemic control but also has demonstrated cardiovascular benefits, which is a key consideration in this patient population.

options.description: Add a sulfonylurea, such as glyburide, as it is effective at lowering blood glucose.
Add a sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor, such as empagliflozin or dapagliflozin.
Continue with metformin alone and recommend more intensive lifestyle modifications for three months.
Immediately initiate basal insulin therapy as his A1c is above 8.0%.

questions.question: Regarding the 1 cm neuropathic ulcer on his right foot, what is the most critical immediate management intervention the NP should initiate in the clinic? The priority is to reduce pressure on the affected area to promote healing and prevent the ulcer from worsening, which is the cornerstone of treating neuropathic foot ulcers.

options.description: Prescribe a course of oral antibiotics, such as cephalexin, to prevent infection.
Perform sharp debridement of the surrounding callus and apply a simple dressing.
Advise him to soak his foot in warm water daily to keep the area clean.
Implement an immediate offloading strategy, such as providing a temporary offloading shoe or footwear, and provide education on its use.

questions.question: When documenting this clinical encounter, which element is most crucial to include to meet professional standards and ensure continuity of care? The documentation must accurately reflect the complexity of the visit, the clinical reasoning involved, and the comprehensive plan put in place to address the patient's multiple active issues, thereby mitigating medicolegal risk and facilitating team-based care.

options.description: A brief note stating 'Diabetes follow-up, A1c 8.1%, continue metformin.'
A record of his vital signs and the date of his next scheduled appointment.

Documentation of the new diagnosis of peripheral neuropathy, the specific characteristics of the foot ulcer (size, location, appearance), the results of the monofilament and vascular exams, the rationale for adding an SGLT2 inhibitor, and the details of the foot care and offloading plan provided.
A note focusing solely on the foot ulcer, deferring documentation of the glycemic control discussion to a future visit.

scenario: A 48-year-old male construction worker attends your primary care clinic for a periodic health review. He feels well with no active complaints. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 52. The patient admits to smoking approximately 10 cigarettes per day and drinking 3-4 beers on weekends. His BMI is 29 kg/m². In-office automated blood pressure readings, taken five minutes apart in a quiet room with proper technique, are 152/94 mmHg and 148/96 mmHg. A review of his chart shows a reading of 135/85 mmHg one year ago. He takes no regular medications.

questions.question: According to the most recent Hypertension Canada guidelines, what is the most appropriate next step to accurately confirm a diagnosis of hypertension for this patient? The goal is to avoid misdiagnosis due to potential 'white coat' effect and to obtain a more comprehensive picture of his blood pressure profile before initiating lifelong therapy, which is a critical decision point in his care.

options.description: Repeat the in-office blood pressure measurement at the end of the current visit.
Prescribe a 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM) study.
Ask the patient to return for three more separate office visits to measure his blood pressure.
Immediately start him on an antihypertensive medication and titrate based on his response.

questions.question: Given his newly identified high blood pressure and multiple cardiovascular risk factors (smoking, family history, overweight), which panel of baseline investigations is most crucial to order to complete his overall cardiovascular risk stratification and screen for target organ damage? This comprehensive workup is essential for guiding the intensity of both lifestyle and pharmacological interventions.

options.description: A serum uric acid and calcium level only.
Standard 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG), fasting lipid panel (including cholesterol, LDL, HDL, triglycerides), fasting glucose or HbA1c, and serum creatinine with eGFR.
A cardiac stress test and a carotid Doppler ultrasound.
A complete blood count (CBC) and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level.

questions.question: His ABPM results confirm hypertension with a 24-hour average of 145/92 mmHg. His baseline lab work is unremarkable except for a moderately elevated LDL cholesterol. According to Hypertension Canada guidelines for a non-diabetic patient with uncomplicated hypertension, which of the following is the most appropriate first-line pharmacological agent to initiate for this patient?

options.description: A beta-blocker, such as metoprolol, because of his family history of MI.
A thiazide-like diuretic (e.g., chlorthalidone or indapamide) or an Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE) inhibitor (e.g., ramipril).
An alpha-blocker, such as doxazosin, as it can be taken once daily.
A loop diuretic, such as furosemide, due to its potent effect on blood pressure.

questions.question: The patient seems overwhelmed by the new diagnosis and the need for medication and lifestyle changes. He states, 'I feel fine, why do I need to do all this stuff?' What is the most effective counselling strategy to enhance his understanding and motivation? Your goal is to use a patient-centered approach that links the diagnosis to his personal values and future health, thereby fostering intrinsic motivation for change.

options.description: Use scare tactics by detailing the worst-case scenarios of untreated hypertension, such as stroke and heart attack.
Provide him with a series of pamphlets on smoking cessation, diet, and exercise and instruct him to read them at home.

Acknowledge his feelings and explain the asymptomatic nature of hypertension. Use a cardiovascular risk calculator to provide a visual, personalized estimate of his 10-year risk, and collaboratively set one or two small, achievable goals for the next visit (e.g., reduce smoking by half).
Inform him that lifestyle changes are mandatory and that failure to comply will result in needing more medications.

questions.subdomain: Transition of Care, Discharge Planning and Documentation
questions.question: To ensure effective long-term management and continuity of care for this patient with a new chronic disease, which documentation entry is most comprehensive and meets professional standards? The entry must serve as a clear baseline, outlining the diagnostic process, risk assessment, shared decision-making, and follow-up plan, which is vital for any future provider and for demonstrating quality of care.

options.description: A brief entry: 'Patient seen for check-up. BP elevated. Started on Ramipril. Follow up in 1 month.'
Documentation of the in-office BP readings, the plan for ABPM, and a note to discuss results at the next visit.

A detailed note including the in-office and ABPM results, documentation of his cardiovascular risk factors (smoking, family history, BMI), a summary of the shared decision-making discussion about initiating medication, the specific medication and dose prescribed, lifestyle goals set, and a clear follow-up plan for BP check and lab monitoring in 4-6 weeks.
A note that only lists the prescribed medication and the patient's allergies.

scenario: A 24-year-old female university student presents to the walk-in clinic with a three-day history of dysuria, urinary frequency, and suprapubic pain. She has no vaginal discharge or irritation. This morning, she began feeling unwell, with right-sided flank pain that she rates as 6/10, and she has had subjective fevers and one episode of nausea. Her temperature in the clinic is 38.4°C and her heart rate is 105 bpm. On examination, she is alert and appears uncomfortable. Abdominal exam is benign, but she has significant right costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness on percussion. A urine dipstick is strongly positive for leukocyte esterase and nitrites.

questions.question: By integrating the patient's acute presentation of lower urinary tract symptoms with the new onset of systemic signs (fever, nausea) and a key physical exam finding (CVA tenderness), what is the most precise and accurate diagnosis? This distinction is critical because it dictates a significant change in the management approach, including the class of antibiotic used and the duration of therapy, compared to a less severe condition.

options.description: Uncomplicated cystitis, as the initial symptoms were localized to the lower tract.
Acute pyelonephritis (complicated UTI), given the constellation of fever, flank pain, and CVA tenderness.
Urethritis, likely from a sexually transmitted infection, which can also cause dysuria.
Nephrolithiasis (kidney stone), as it can present with flank pain and nausea.

questions.question: While a clinical diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis is strongly suspected, which investigation is the most important to perform at this initial visit? The purpose of this test is not only to confirm the presence of bacteria but, more importantly, to guide future therapy if the patient fails to respond to the initial empirical treatment, which is a key safety consideration in managing complicated infections.

options.description: A renal ultrasound to rule out a kidney abscess.
A complete blood count (CBC) to assess for leukocytosis.
A midstream urine for culture and sensitivity (C&S).
A serum creatinine level to assess her baseline renal function.

questions.question: The patient is non-toxic, able to tolerate oral fluids, and has no other comorbidities. Based on Canadian guidelines for outpatient management of uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis, which of the following is the most appropriate initial antibiotic choice? This choice must reflect current antimicrobial stewardship principles and known resistance patterns for the most likely uropathogen, E. coli.

options.description: A 3-day course of nitrofurantoin.
A 7 to 10-day course of an oral fluoroquinolone, such as ciprofloxacin.
A single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone.
A 5-day course of amoxicillin.

questions.question: After prescribing the appropriate antibiotic, you must decide on the disposition for this patient. Considering she is clinically stable, tolerating fluids, and has reliable access to follow-up, what is the most critical factor that would shift your decision from safe outpatient management to recommending immediate hospital admission? This requires the NP to critically evaluate the patient's overall clinical picture for signs of impending sepsis or complications that cannot be managed in the community.

options.description: The presence of moderate flank pain, rated 6/10.
The patient expresses anxiety about being managed at home.
The presence of hemodynamic instability, such as hypotension (e.g., BP 90/50 mmHg), persistent vomiting precluding oral intake, or signs of septic shock.
A urine dipstick that is strongly positive for both nitrites and leukocyte esterase.

questions.question: Before she leaves the clinic, you provide discharge counselling. What is the single most important piece of advice to give her to ensure her safety? This counselling must be clear, actionable, and emphasize specific red-flag symptoms that would necessitate an immediate return for medical care, which is a crucial part of safe outpatient management for potentially serious infections.

options.description: Advise her to drink plenty of cranberry juice and to complete the full course of antibiotics.
Instruct her on proper perineal hygiene to prevent future infections.

Clearly state that she must seek immediate medical attention if her symptoms worsen, if the fever persists beyond 48 hours of starting antibiotics, or if she develops new vomiting and cannot keep the medication down.
Recommend she takes a probiotic supplement alongside her antibiotic to prevent diarrhea.

scenario: A 16-year-old female, is brought to your primary care clinic by her mother. Her mother is concerned because her grades have dropped from A's to C's over the past semester and she has stopped participating in her soccer team. When you speak to the patient alone, she reports feeling 'sad and blah' most days for the last four months. She has low energy, finds it hard to concentrate in class, and often wakes up in the middle of the night, unable to get back to sleep. She denies any plans for self-harm but admits to sometimes feeling like 'it would be easier if I just wasn't here.' She denies substance use.

questions.question: When assessing this adolescent patient, what is the most critical and immediate priority for the Nurse Practitioner, even though the patient has denied having a specific plan for self-harm? The NP's primary responsibility is to ensure patient safety, and this requires a deeper, more direct exploration of a key risk area that is prevalent in adolescent depression, going beyond the initial denial.

options.description: A detailed exploration of her academic performance and reasons for her grades dropping.
A comprehensive dietary assessment to rule out nutritional deficiencies.
A thorough and direct assessment of suicidal ideation, including its frequency, intensity, and any associated preparatory behaviors, as well as protective factors.
An investigation into her peer relationships and potential bullying at school.

questions.question: To augment your clinical interview and objectively quantify the severity of her depressive symptoms, which of the following actions would be most appropriate in a Canadian primary care setting? The use of a validated tool provides a standardized baseline, helps in monitoring treatment response over time, and facilitates communication with other healthcare professionals, such as mental health specialists.

options.description: Relying solely on your clinical impression of her mood and affect during the interview.
Administering a validated, self-report screening tool such as the Patient Health Questionnaire for Adolescents (PHQ-A) or the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI).
Asking her mother to fill out a questionnaire about the patient's behaviour.
Ordering laboratory tests, including a TSH and CBC, as the primary method to assess for depression.

questions.question: Her PHQ-A score indicates moderate depression. She has a supportive family and no signs of psychosis or immediate safety concerns. According to Canadian practice guidelines for mild-to-moderate depression in adolescents, what is the most appropriate initial management plan for the NP to propose? The plan should prioritize evidence-based, lower-risk interventions before considering medications.

options.description: Immediately initiate a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), such as fluoxetine.
Recommend watchful waiting and schedule a follow-up appointment in three months.

Propose a trial of psychotherapy (such as Cognitive Behavioural Therapy or Interpersonal Therapy) and provide psychoeducation on sleep hygiene, physical activity, and nutrition, with a plan for close follow-up in 2-4 weeks.
Suggest an over-the-counter herbal supplement like St. John's Wort.

questions.question: During the counselling portion of the visit with both the patient and her mother, the mother asks if starting an antidepressant right away wouldn't be faster. How should the NP best address this question while supporting the recommended plan and managing parental expectations? The response should be educational, collaborative, and reinforce the rationale for the chosen therapeutic approach.

options.description: State that medications are a last resort and should be avoided in teenagers.

Explain that while medications can be very helpful and may be considered later, guidelines recommend starting with therapy and lifestyle strategies first because they provide lifelong coping skills. Also mention the 'black box' warning for SSRIs in adolescents, emphasizing the need for careful consideration and monitoring if they are used.
Agree with the mother and provide a prescription for an SSRI to satisfy her request.
Tell the mother that therapy is more effective than medication in all cases of adolescent depression.

questions.subdomain: Transition of Care, Discharge Planning and Documentation
questions.question: To facilitate a collaborative, team-based approach to the patient's care, you plan to connect with the school's guidance counsellor (with patient and parent consent). What is the most important information to communicate to the school counsellor? The goal is to provide relevant information that allows the counsellor to support the student effectively within the school environment, while respecting patient privacy and confidentiality.

options.description: A detailed transcript of your entire clinical conversation with the patient.
Only the formal medical diagnosis of 'Major Depressive Disorder'.

A summary of the patient's functional impairments at school (e.g., difficulty concentrating, social withdrawal), the general nature of the treatment plan (e.g., 'is engaged in therapy'), and a request for potential academic accommodations, such as extended time for assignments.
A request for the counsellor to take over all management of the patient's mental health.

scenario: A mother brings her 4-year-old son to your primary care clinic. She reports he had a high fever, reaching 39.5°C, for the past three days, during which he was irritable and had a poor appetite. This morning, she was relieved to find his temperature was normal, but then she noticed a rash. The rash is described as pinkish-red, with small, flat spots and some raised bumps (maculopapular). It started on his trunk and has begun spreading to his neck and upper arms. On examination, the child is afebrile, alert, and playful. The rash is non-pruritic and blanches with pressure. You also note some mild posterior cervical lymphadenopathy.

questions.question: By critically analyzing the classic sequence of clinical events—a period of high fever that abruptly resolves, immediately followed by the appearance of a maculopapular rash starting on the trunk—what is the most likely diagnosis for this well-appearing child? This specific temporal relationship between fever and rash is the pathognomonic feature that distinguishes this condition from other common childhood viral exanthems.

options.description: Measles (Rubeola), which is characterized by a prodrome of cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis.
Rubella (German Measles), which typically presents with a lower-grade fever and a rash that starts on the face.
Roseola infantum (Exanthem subitum), caused by Human Herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6).
Erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease), which is known for its 'slapped-cheek' facial rash.

questions.question: Despite the classic presentation of Roseola, the Nurse Practitioner must always consider more serious conditions in a child presenting with fever and rash. Which of the following physical exam findings, if present, would be a significant red flag, warranting an immediate change in the diagnostic consideration towards a more serious illness like meningitis or Kawasaki disease, and prompting urgent escalation of care?

options.description: The presence of a non-blanching, petechial or purpuric rash.
A rash that is concentrated on the trunk and neck.
The child appearing irritable during the febrile phase of the illness.
Mildly swollen posterior cervical lymph nodes.

questions.question: Having confidently diagnosed the child with Roseola infantum, what is the most appropriate management plan for the NP to recommend to the mother? This requires an understanding that Roseola is a benign, self-limiting viral illness, and management should focus on parental reassurance and symptomatic care, avoiding unnecessary interventions as per antimicrobial stewardship principles.

options.description: Prescribe a 7-day course of amoxicillin to prevent secondary bacterial infection.
Recommend supportive care only, including ensuring adequate fluid intake, and using antipyretics like acetaminophen or ibuprofen for fever-related discomfort if the fever were to return.
Refer the child to a dermatologist for a specialist opinion on the rash.
Advise the application of a topical hydrocortisone cream to the rash to help it resolve faster.

questions.question: The mother is concerned about her 1-year-old nephew who was playing with her son two days ago, during the febrile phase. How should the NP counsel the mother regarding the typical period of communicability for Roseola? This advice is important for public health, preventing unnecessary quarantine, and providing the family with accurate information to allay their fears.

options.description: Inform her that the child is most contagious now that the rash has appeared and should be isolated for another week.

Explain that the period of communicability is primarily during the high fever phase, before the rash appears, through respiratory secretions. Once the fever has resolved for 24 hours, the child is generally no longer considered contagious.
Advise that Roseola is not contagious at any stage.
Tell her that her nephew should be brought in for prophylactic antiviral medication.

questions.question: To ensure the clinical record is clear and accurately reflects the basis for your diagnosis, which documentation element is most essential? A precise and detailed note justifies the diagnosis of a benign condition, which is particularly important in cases of fever and rash where more serious illnesses are on the differential, and it supports the decision to provide reassurance and minimal intervention.

options.description: A note stating '4-year-old with viral rash. Reassured mother. Follow up as needed.'
Documentation that a rash is present and the child is afebrile today.

A detailed description of the classic history: a 3-day high fever that resolved abruptly, followed by the onset of a blanching maculopapular rash on the trunk. Also note the child's well-appearance and afebrile state at the time of examination to support the diagnosis of Roseola and rule out more concerning conditions.
A list of all possible viral exanthems that were considered in the differential diagnosis.

scenario: An 82-year-old female, accompanied by her daughter, presents to a primary care clinic with concerns about her memory. The daughter reports that her mother has been increasingly forgetful over the past year, frequently misplacing items and repeating questions. Recently, she got lost while driving home from the grocery store, a route she has taken for over 40 years. The patient has a history of hypertension, well-controlled on ramipril, and osteoarthritis for which she takes acetaminophen as needed. She lives alone and has been a widow for ten years. On examination, she appears well-groomed but is oriented to person and place only. She scores 19/30 on the MoCA, with significant deficits in delayed recall and executive function.

questions.question: The patient's daughter expresses significant concern about her mother's ability to continue living alone safely. In addition to the cognitive assessment already performed, which of the following assessment areas is most critical for the Nurse Practitioner to explore in detail to evaluate the patient's functional independence and immediate safety risks? A comprehensive evaluation of this area will provide the most objective data to guide discussions about living arrangements.

options.description: A detailed nutritional assessment, including a 3-day food diary and screening for malnutrition.
A thorough review of her financial management skills, including her ability to pay bills and handle a bank account.
An evaluation of her Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADLs), focusing on medication management, telephone use, and meal preparation.
A focused social history, exploring the extent of her social network and participation in community activities.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Cognitive Impairment

questions.question: The patient's MoCA score is 19/30, indicating significant cognitive impairment. To differentiate between potential underlying causes and rule out reversible factors, which set of initial laboratory investigations would be most appropriate for the Nurse Practitioner to order for this patient? This panel is essential to exclude common metabolic and nutritional deficiencies that can mimic or exacerbate dementia syndromes in the elderly.

options.description: Complete blood count (CBC), thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), serum vitamin B12, and electrolytes.
Lipid panel, liver function tests (LFTs), and C-reactive protein (CRP).
Urinalysis, fasting glucose, and glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c).
Serum calcium, folate levels, and a toxicology screen.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Cognitive Impairment

questions.question: Given the insidious onset and progressive nature of the memory loss, the deficits in delayed recall and executive function on the MoCA, and the significant functional impact (getting lost while driving), what is the most likely diagnosis for this patient? The clinical presentation is classic for a primary neurodegenerative disorder, and distinguishing it from other forms of dementia is key for management.

options.description: Vascular Dementia, given her history of hypertension.
Lewy Body Dementia, considering potential fluctuations in cognition.
Delirium, related to a possible underlying infection.
Alzheimer's Disease, based on the classic amnestic presentation and functional decline.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Cognitive Impairment

questions.question: After diagnosing the patient with probable Alzheimer's disease, the daughter asks about medication options. The Nurse Practitioner considers starting a cholinesterase inhibitor. According to Canadian best practice guidelines, which of the following is the most appropriate initial management step regarding pharmacotherapy for this patient's cognitive symptoms? This approach balances initiating evidence-based treatment while ensuring patient safety and appropriateness.

options.description: Immediately prescribe a high dose of donepezil to achieve rapid therapeutic effect and slow disease progression.
Refer the patient directly to a geriatric psychiatrist for initiation of memantine, as it has a better side effect profile.
Initiate a low-dose trial of a cholinesterase inhibitor, such as donepezil 5 mg daily, and schedule a follow-up in 4-6 weeks to assess for tolerance and efficacy.
Recommend against any pharmacological treatment at this stage and suggest focusing solely on non-pharmacological interventions like cognitive stimulation therapy.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Cognitive Impairment

questions.subdomain: Transition of Care / Discharge Planning / Documentation
questions.question: The Nurse Practitioner has determined that the patient is no longer safe to drive due to her cognitive impairment and functional decline. What is the most appropriate and legally mandated action the NP must take to ensure patient and public safety? This action is a critical part of the transition plan and reflects the NP's responsibility to report medically unfit drivers.

options.description: Strongly advise the patient and her daughter that she should stop driving immediately and document this conversation in the chart.
Report the patient's condition to the provincial Ministry of Transportation by completing and submitting the required medical fitness to drive form.
Arrange a family meeting to discuss a 'driving contract' where the patient agrees to only drive during the day and on familiar routes.
Refer the patient for a formal on-road driving assessment with an occupational therapist before taking any further action.

scenario: A 24-year-old male presents to a walk-in clinic with a 3-day history of a pruritic rash. The rash started on his trunk and has since spread to his arms and legs. He describes the initial lesion as a single, larger, oval-shaped pink patch on his abdomen that appeared about a week before the generalized rash. He denies any recent changes in detergents, soaps, or lotions and has not started any new medications. He is otherwise healthy, with no significant past medical history, and is up-to-date on his immunizations. On examination, there is a diffuse eruption of small, pink-to-red papules and plaques with fine scale, oriented in a 'Christmas tree' pattern on his back. The larger 'herald patch' is noted on his abdomen.

questions.question: The patient's clinical presentation is highly suggestive of pityriasis rosea. However, it is crucial to rule out secondary syphilis, which can present with a similar rash. Which of the following questions is most important for the Nurse Practitioner to ask to help differentiate between these two conditions? The answer to this question can provide critical information regarding the risk of a sexually transmitted infection.

options.description: "Have you recently traveled to any tropical countries or been hiking in wooded areas?"
"Have you experienced any fever, sore throat, or swollen glands recently?"
"Do you have any personal or family history of eczema, psoriasis, or other skin conditions?"
"Have you had any new sexual partners in the last few months, and have you noticed any sores on your genitals, mouth, or anus?"

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Skin Rashes

questions.question: Based on the history of a herald patch followed by a generalized eruption in a 'Christmas tree' distribution, and the absence of other risk factors, what is the most likely diagnosis for this patient? Correctly identifying this common, self-limiting condition is key to avoiding unnecessary investigations and treatments.

options.description: Guttate Psoriasis
Pityriasis Rosea
Secondary Syphilis
Tinea Corporis

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Skin Rashes

questions.question: The patient is diagnosed with pityriasis rosea and is complaining of significant pruritus that is interfering with his sleep. According to evidence-based guidelines for symptomatic relief of this condition, what is the most appropriate initial management plan the Nurse Practitioner should recommend? This approach focuses on safe and effective symptom control for a self-resolving condition.

options.description: Prescribe a course of oral acyclovir 800 mg five times daily for seven days to treat the suspected viral cause.
Recommend using lukewarm baths, emollients, and a medium-potency topical corticosteroid like betamethasone valerate 0.1% cream applied to pruritic areas twice daily.
Advise the patient to get natural sunlight exposure for 10-15 minutes daily and prescribe a short course of oral prednisone.
Refer the patient to a dermatologist for urgent phototherapy, as this is the first-line treatment for pruritus in pityriasis rosea.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Skin Rashes

questions.question: The patient is concerned about the appearance of the rash and asks if he is contagious to his partner. What is the most appropriate counselling for the Nurse Practitioner to provide regarding the nature of pityriasis rosea and its transmission? Providing accurate reassurance and education is a key component of managing this condition.

options.description: "The rash is highly contagious through direct skin-to-skin contact, so you should avoid all physical contact with your partner until the rash is completely gone."
"Pityriasis rosea is generally not considered to be contagious, and transmission to close contacts is rare. You do not need to take any special precautions with your partner."
"The condition is caused by a fungus and can be spread through shared towels and bedding, so you must launder all your linens in hot water immediately."
"While the exact cause is unknown, it's thought to be an allergic reaction, so you should identify and eliminate the trigger to prevent spreading it."

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Skin Rashes

questions.subdomain: Transition of Care / Discharge Planning / Documentation
questions.question: The patient has been provided with a diagnosis and management plan. What is the most crucial information the Nurse Practitioner must provide to the patient regarding the expected course of the illness and when he should seek follow-up care? This ensures the patient is well-informed and can self-monitor appropriately, preventing unnecessary return visits while ensuring safety.

options.description: Advise the patient that the rash should resolve within one week and to return if it persists beyond that time.
Inform the patient that the rash is a chronic condition that will require long-term management with a dermatologist.

Explain that the rash typically resolves on its own over 6-8 weeks, but he should return if the rash changes in appearance, becomes painful, involves the palms or soles, or if he develops a fever or sores in his mouth.
Provide a follow-up appointment for the next day to monitor for any signs of secondary bacterial infection.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Skin Rashes

scenario: A 16-year-old female presents to a community health clinic with her mother, reporting heavy and painful menstrual periods since menarche at age 13. Her periods last 7-9 days, and she soaks through a super tampon or pad every 1-2 hours for the first three days. She describes the pain as a severe cramping in her lower abdomen that radiates to her back, rating it an 8/10, which often causes her to miss school. She has tried over-the-counter ibuprofen with minimal relief. She is otherwise healthy, not sexually active, and her family history is non-contributory. On examination, her vital signs are stable, and her abdominal and pelvic exams are unremarkable. A complete blood count reveals a hemoglobin of 105 g/L and a ferritin of 10 µg/L.

questions.question: The patient's history is concerning for heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB) and dysmenorrhea, and her lab results confirm iron deficiency anemia. To complete a comprehensive assessment and rule out an underlying bleeding disorder, which of the following is the most important additional investigation for the Nurse Practitioner to consider? This is particularly important in an adolescent presenting with HMB since menarche.

options.description: A pelvic ultrasound to assess for uterine fibroids or polyps.
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and prolactin levels.
A coagulation screen including prothrombin time (PT), partial thromboplastin time (PTT), and von Willebrand factor antigen and activity.
Testing for chlamydia and gonorrhea to rule out pelvic inflammatory disease.

questions.reference: Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists of Canada (SOGC) Guidelines

questions.question: Based on the patient's presentation of cyclical, crampy pelvic pain, heavy bleeding since menarche, a normal physical exam, and evidence of iron deficiency anemia, what is the most appropriate working diagnosis? This diagnosis encompasses her primary symptoms and guides the initial management plan.

options.description: Secondary Dysmenorrhea due to Endometriosis
Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
Primary Dysmenorrhea with Heavy Menstrual Bleeding
Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)

questions.reference: Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists of Canada (SOGC) Guidelines

questions.question: The Nurse Practitioner plans to initiate treatment to manage the patient's dysmenorrhea and heavy menstrual bleeding. Given that she has tried NSAIDs with minimal relief and is not sexually active, what is the most appropriate first-line pharmacological management strategy according to Canadian guidelines? This strategy aims to address both pain and bleeding effectively.

options.description: Prescribe a higher dose of a different NSAID, such as naproxen, to be taken on a scheduled basis starting 1-2 days before her period.
Initiate a combined hormonal contraceptive (CHC) pill, to be taken cyclically or continuously, to regulate cycles, reduce bleeding, and suppress ovulation.
Prescribe tranexamic acid to be taken only during her period to specifically target the heavy bleeding.
Refer the patient for the insertion of a levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS).

questions.reference: Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists of Canada (SOGC) Guidelines

questions.question: In addition to managing her menstrual symptoms, the Nurse Practitioner must address the patient's iron deficiency anemia (hemoglobin 105 g/L, ferritin 10 µg/L). What is the most appropriate plan for iron supplementation? The goal is to replete her iron stores and correct the anemia caused by her heavy menstrual bleeding.

options.description: Recommend she increase her intake of iron-rich foods like red meat and leafy greens, and recheck her CBC in 3 months.
Prescribe a daily oral iron supplement, such as ferrous fumarate 300 mg (100 mg elemental iron) once daily, and advise taking it with vitamin C to enhance absorption.
Refer the patient for an intravenous iron infusion, as her hemoglobin is too low for oral supplementation to be effective.
Prescribe a low-dose iron supplement found in a daily multivitamin to avoid gastrointestinal side effects.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Iron Deficiency Anemia

questions.question: When discussing the initiation of a combined hormonal contraceptive (CHC), the patient's mother expresses concern about potential side effects and long-term risks. What is the most appropriate way for the Nurse Practitioner to counsel the patient and her mother? This requires providing balanced information, addressing concerns, and engaging in shared decision-making.

options.description: Focus solely on the benefits for menstrual symptoms and reassure them that side effects are very rare and not a significant concern.
Provide a detailed list of all possible adverse effects, including the increased risk of blood clots, and suggest they take some time to think about it before making a decision.

Acknowledge their concerns, discuss both the common, manageable side effects (e.g., nausea, breast tenderness) and the rare but serious risks (e.g., VTE), while also explaining the non-contraceptive benefits and the plan for follow-up and monitoring.
Explain that since the patient is not sexually active, the risks of CHCs likely outweigh the benefits, and recommend sticking to non-hormonal options.

questions.reference: Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists of Canada (SOGC) Guidelines

scenario: A 58-year-old male construction worker presents to a primary care clinic complaining of a gritty, burning sensation in both eyes that has been worsening over the past few months. He reports his eyes are often red, and his eyelids feel 'heavy' and itchy, especially in the mornings. He notes some crusting along his eyelashes upon waking. He has tried over-the-counter lubricating eye drops with only temporary relief. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes, managed with metformin, and hyperlipidemia, for which he takes a statin. He denies any changes in vision, photophobia, or eye discharge. On examination, his visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. Slit-lamp examination reveals telangiectasias and erythema of the eyelid margins, with scaly debris at the base of the eyelashes.

questions.question: The patient's symptoms and examination findings are consistent with blepharitis. Given his history of type 2 diabetes, which of the following is the most important additional assessment for the Nurse Practitioner to perform during this visit? This assessment is critical because systemic conditions can have significant ocular manifestations, and this patient is due for routine screening.

options.description: A detailed assessment of his occupational exposures to dust and debris at the construction site.
Screening for symptoms of dry mouth and joint pain to rule out Sjögren's syndrome.
A fundoscopic exam to screen for diabetic retinopathy, and confirming when his last formal diabetic eye exam was performed by an optometrist or ophthalmologist.
Checking for preauricular lymphadenopathy to rule out a viral cause for his symptoms.

questions.question: Based on the clinical findings of eyelid margin erythema, telangiectasias, and crusting debris at the base of the eyelashes, in conjunction with the patient's symptoms of burning, grittiness, and itching, what is the most specific diagnosis? This chronic inflammatory condition is common and has a characteristic presentation.

options.description: Allergic Conjunctivitis
Anterior Blepharitis
Episcleritis
Hordeolum (Stye)

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Eye Conditions

questions.question: The Nurse Practitioner is formulating a management plan for the patient's anterior blepharitis. What is the most appropriate first-line, non-pharmacological management strategy that should be taught to the patient? This foundational step is crucial for long-term control of symptoms and prevention of exacerbations.

options.description: Prescribing a combination antibiotic-corticosteroid eye drop to be used four times daily.
Recommending the patient wear safety glasses at all times, both at work and at home.

Instructing the patient on a daily routine of warm compresses applied to the eyelids for 5-10 minutes, followed by gentle eyelid margin scrubbing with a commercial lid cleanser or diluted baby shampoo.
Advising a trial of an over-the-counter antihistamine eye drop to manage the itching.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Eye Conditions

questions.question: If the patient's symptoms of blepharitis do not improve sufficiently with eyelid hygiene alone, what would be the next appropriate pharmacological step for the Nurse Practitioner to consider? This step involves adding a topical medication to reduce the bacterial load and inflammation at the eyelid margin.

options.description: A course of oral doxycycline to address meibomian gland dysfunction.
Topical erythromycin or bacitracin ophthalmic ointment applied to the eyelid margins at bedtime.
Topical cyclosporine eye drops to increase tear production.
A referral to an ophthalmologist for a surgical procedure to unblock the meibomian glands.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Eye Conditions

questions.question: The patient is frustrated with his symptoms and wants to know if there is a 'quick fix'. How should the Nurse Practitioner counsel him regarding the expected course and management of blepharitis? Effective counselling is essential for setting realistic expectations and promoting adherence to the treatment plan.

options.description: Inform him that a short course of antibiotic eye drops will cure the condition completely within a week.

Explain that blepharitis is a chronic condition that often has periods of exacerbation and remission, and that consistent, long-term eyelid hygiene is the most important factor for controlling symptoms.
Advise him that his symptoms are likely due to his diabetes and will only improve once his blood sugar is perfectly controlled.
Reassure him that the condition is benign and will resolve on its own without any treatment, so he should just continue with lubricating drops.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Eye Conditions

scenario: A 55-year-old man with a 35-pack-year smoking history presents to his primary care NP with a persistent cough and increasing shortness of breath over the past six months. He describes his cough as productive of white sputum, especially in the mornings. He becomes dyspneic after walking up one flight of stairs or walking about 100 meters on level ground. He has had two episodes of 'chest colds' in the past year that required antibiotics and oral steroids. He has a history of hypertension controlled with an ACE inhibitor. On examination, he is afebrile, with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths/minute and an oxygen saturation of 91% on room air. Auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds bilaterally and scattered wheezes. He has a notable barrel chest and uses accessory muscles for respiration.

questions.question: The patient's history and physical examination are highly suggestive of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). To confirm the diagnosis and classify the severity of airflow limitation, which of the following diagnostic tests is considered the gold standard and is essential for the Nurse Practitioner to order? This test provides objective evidence of airflow obstruction and is critical for guiding therapeutic decisions.

options.description: A chest X-ray to assess for hyperinflation and bullae.
Spirometry with pre- and post-bronchodilator measurements.
A high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) scan of the chest.
An arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis to determine the level of hypoxemia and hypercapnia.

questions.question: The post-bronchodilator spirometry results show a FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.65 and an FEV1 of 45% of predicted. Based on the Canadian Thoracic Society (CTS) guidelines, how would the Nurse Practitioner correctly classify the severity of this patient's airflow limitation? Accurate classification is fundamental to initiating the appropriate pharmacological and non-pharmacological management.

options.description: Mild airflow limitation.
Moderate airflow limitation.
Severe airflow limitation.
Very severe airflow limitation.

questions.question: Given the patient's diagnosis of severe COPD, significant symptoms (dyspnea on minimal exertion), and history of two exacerbations in the past year, what is the most appropriate initial pharmacological management strategy according to the 2023 CTS guidelines? The goal is to optimize bronchodilation, reduce exacerbation risk, and improve quality of life.

options.description: A short-acting beta-agonist (SABA) as needed for symptom relief.
A long-acting muscarinic antagonist (LAMA) monotherapy.
Combination therapy with a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA) and a long-acting muscarinic antagonist (LAMA).
Triple therapy with a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA), a long-acting muscarinic antagonist (LAMA), and an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS).

questions.question: The patient expresses a desire to quit smoking but feels discouraged after several failed attempts. What is the most effective evidence-based counselling approach for the Nurse Practitioner to use to support his smoking cessation efforts? This approach combines behavioral support and pharmacotherapy to maximize the chances of a successful quit attempt.

options.description: Advise him to try again using willpower alone and provide him with a pamphlet on the benefits of quitting.
Strongly recommend he switch to vaping (e-cigarettes) as a less harmful alternative to smoking.
Use the '5 A's' model (Ask, Advise, Assess, Assist, Arrange) to provide structured counselling and offer combination pharmacotherapy, such as varenicline or nicotine replacement therapy (NRT).
Focus only on managing his COPD symptoms and suggest addressing smoking cessation at a later date when he feels more ready.

questions.subdomain: Transition of Care / Discharge Planning / Documentation
questions.question: The patient is being started on triple therapy and counselled on smoking cessation. To ensure comprehensive care and reduce the risk of future exacerbations, which of the following referrals is most important for the Nurse Practitioner to initiate as part of the patient's ongoing management plan? This referral provides structured education and exercise training, which is a cornerstone of COPD management.

options.description: A referral to a thoracic surgeon for consideration of lung volume reduction surgery.
A referral to a pulmonary rehabilitation program.
A referral to a registered dietitian for nutritional counselling.
A referral for home oxygen therapy assessment.

scenario: A 4-year-old boy is brought to an urgent care clinic by his father with a 5-day history of high fever, ranging from 39°C to 40°C. The father reports the fever has been minimally responsive to acetaminophen and ibuprofen. Over the past two days, the child has developed red eyes, cracked red lips, a 'strawberry tongue,' and a diffuse maculopapular rash on his trunk and extremities. He has also been extremely irritable. On examination, the child is febrile at 39.5°C, tachycardic, and has bilateral non-exudative conjunctivitis, prominent cervical lymphadenopathy on the left side, and erythema and swelling of his hands and feet.

questions.question: The patient's constellation of symptoms is highly concerning for Kawasaki disease. In addition to the physical findings already noted, which of the following assessments is most critical for the Nurse Practitioner to perform to support the diagnosis and identify potential complications? This assessment focuses on the organ system most severely affected by Kawasaki disease.

options.description: A thorough neurological exam, including assessment for meningeal signs.
A detailed cardiac examination, specifically listening for a gallop rhythm, new murmurs, or muffled heart sounds.
Abdominal palpation to assess for hepatosplenomegaly.
A joint examination to look for evidence of arthritis.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Kawasaki Disease

questions.question: The patient presents with fever for 5 days plus four of the five principal clinical criteria (bilateral conjunctivitis, oral mucosal changes, polymorphous rash, extremity changes, and cervical lymphadenopathy). Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis? Prompt recognition is crucial to prevent long-term sequelae.

options.description: Measles (Rubeola)
Scarlet Fever
Kawasaki Disease
Stevens-Johnson Syndrome

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Kawasaki Disease

questions.question: After confirming the diagnosis of Kawasaki disease, what is the most critical and time-sensitive management step the Nurse Practitioner must take to reduce the risk of coronary artery aneurysms? This intervention is the standard of care and should be initiated as soon as possible.

options.description: Administer a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics to treat a possible underlying bacterial infection.
Start a high-dose oral corticosteroid taper to reduce systemic inflammation.
Immediately transfer the patient to a hospital for inpatient administration of high-dose intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) and high-dose aspirin.
Prescribe high-dose ibuprofen for fever and pain control and arrange for outpatient cardiology follow-up in one week.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Kawasaki Disease

questions.question: The patient's father is very worried and asks about the long-term outlook for his son. What is the most appropriate information for the Nurse Practitioner to provide regarding the prognosis of Kawasaki disease? This counselling should be realistic, addressing both the benefits of timely treatment and the need for long-term monitoring.

options.description: Reassure him that once the fever resolves with treatment, there are no long-term health concerns or need for follow-up.
Explain that Kawasaki disease is a self-limiting illness and that treatment is only for symptom comfort, with no impact on long-term outcomes.

Inform him that with timely IVIG treatment, the risk of coronary artery problems is significantly reduced, but his son will require long-term follow-up with a pediatric cardiologist, including echocardiograms, to monitor his heart.
Advise him that all children with Kawasaki disease will develop permanent heart damage, but it can be managed with lifelong medication.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Kawasaki Disease

questions.subdomain: Transition of Care / Discharge Planning / Documentation
questions.question: Upon discharge from the hospital, the patient will be on low-dose aspirin for several weeks. What crucial piece of anticipatory guidance must the Nurse Practitioner provide to the parents regarding immunizations? This information is vital to prevent a serious complication related to aspirin therapy in children.

options.description: All scheduled immunizations should be given on time without any changes to the standard schedule.
He should receive an extra dose of the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine to boost his immunity.

The administration of live virus vaccines, specifically the MMR and varicella vaccines, should be deferred for at least 11 months after receiving IVIG. The annual influenza vaccine is recommended but should be the inactivated (injected) form.
He should not receive any further immunizations until he is cleared by an infectious disease specialist.

scenario: A 48-year-old woman presents for a follow-up appointment after routine screening labs revealed a fasting plasma glucose of 8.2 mmol/L and an HbA1c of 7.8%. She has a family history of type 2 diabetes. Her BMI is 32 kg/m². She reports experiencing increased thirst and frequent urination over the last few months but has attributed it to drinking more water. She has a history of hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially. On examination, her blood pressure is 138/88 mmHg. The rest of her physical exam, including a foot exam, is unremarkable.

questions.question: The patient has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and hypertension. According to the Diabetes Canada guidelines, which of the following assessments is a crucial component of the initial evaluation to screen for microvascular complications and establish a baseline for ongoing management? This should be performed at the time of diagnosis.

options.description: A 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring test.
A carotid Doppler ultrasound to assess for atherosclerosis.
A urine test for albumin-to-creatinine ratio (ACR) and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR).
An ankle-brachial index (ABI) to screen for peripheral artery disease.

questions.question: The patient's blood pressure is 138/88 mmHg on hydrochlorothiazide. Given her new diagnosis of type 2 diabetes, what is the most appropriate next step in the assessment and management of her hypertension according to Diabetes Canada guidelines? The goal is to optimize blood pressure control to reduce cardiovascular risk.

options.description: Continue the current dose of hydrochlorothiazide and recheck her blood pressure in 6 months.
Discontinue the hydrochlorothiazide as it can worsen hyperglycemia.
Add an ACE inhibitor or an ARB to her regimen, as this is the first-line recommendation for hypertension in patients with diabetes, and titrate to achieve a target of <130/80 mmHg.
Advise her to focus on lifestyle modifications, including a low-sodium diet and exercise, before considering any changes to her medication.

questions.question: The Nurse Practitioner is initiating pharmacotherapy for the patient's newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes. Given her clinical profile (no history of cardiovascular disease or kidney disease), what is the most appropriate first-line medication to prescribe according to Diabetes Canada guidelines? This agent is recommended due to its efficacy, low risk of hypoglycemia, and potential for modest weight loss.

options.description: A sulfonylurea, such as glyburide, to stimulate insulin secretion.
Basal insulin to be started immediately to achieve rapid glycemic control.
Metformin, starting at a low dose and titrating up as tolerated to minimize gastrointestinal side effects.
A SGLT2 inhibitor, such as empagliflozin, as it is the preferred first-line agent for all patients with type 2 diabetes.

questions.question: The patient feels overwhelmed by her new diagnosis of type 2 diabetes.
