What is the most crucial initial counselling point the Nurse Practitioner should focus on to empower the patient and promote self-management? This initial step lays the foundation for all subsequent education and treatment.

options.description: Providing a detailed and complex meal plan with strict carbohydrate counting.
Emphasizing the importance of self-monitoring of blood glucose (SMBG) at least four times per day.

Referring her to a certified diabetes educator (CDE) and a registered dietitian for comprehensive, structured education on lifestyle modification, including healthy eating and physical activity, and explaining that she is the most important member of her diabetes care team.
Focusing the discussion on all the potential long-term complications of diabetes to motivate her to adhere to treatment.

questions.subdomain: Transition of Care / Discharge Planning / Documentation
questions.question: The Nurse Practitioner has initiated metformin and an ACE inhibitor and provided initial counselling. What is the most appropriate follow-up plan to document to ensure timely reassessment of glycemic control and medication tolerance? This plan adheres to standard of care for newly diagnosed diabetes.

options.description: Schedule a follow-up appointment in one year to recheck her HbA1c.
Arrange for a telephone follow-up in one week to ask about medication side effects and a clinic visit in 3 months to recheck her HbA1c, blood pressure, and renal function.
Ask her to return in 6 months for a full review.
Tell her to only return if she feels her symptoms of hyperglycemia are not improving.

scenario: A 72-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with a 3-day history of a painful, blistering rash on the right side of her chest. She describes the initial sensation as a burning, tingling pain, which was followed by the eruption of the rash. The pain is severe, rated 9/10, and is not relieved by over-the-counter analgesics. Her past medical history is significant for osteoarthritis and a previous episode of shingles on her face five years ago. She is up-to-date on her immunizations but is unsure if she ever received the shingles vaccine. On examination, there is a unilateral, dermatomal eruption of vesicles on an erythematous base extending from her mid-back to her sternum on the right side at the T4 level.

questions.question: The patient's presentation is classic for herpes zoster (shingles). Given her previous episode on the face, which of the following is the most critical assessment the Nurse Practitioner must perform now to rule out a potentially sight-threatening complication? This specific sign indicates involvement of a branch of the trigeminal nerve that innervates the eye.

options.description: A full neurological exam of the lower extremities to check for motor weakness.
Palpation of the temporal arteries to rule out giant cell arteritis.
Careful inspection of the tip of her nose for any vesicles (Hutchinson's sign).
Auscultation of her lungs to check for any signs of pneumonia.

questions.question: Based on the characteristic unilateral, dermatomal, vesicular rash preceded by neuropathic pain, what is the definitive diagnosis? This viral disease is a reactivation of a latent infection.

options.description: Contact Dermatitis
Herpes Zoster (Shingles)
Impetigo
Cellulitis

questions.question: The patient's rash started 3 days ago. To reduce the severity and duration of the acute illness and to decrease the risk of post-herpetic neuralgia (PHN), what is the most appropriate management plan? Timely initiation of treatment is key.

options.description: Prescribe a topical antibiotic cream to prevent secondary bacterial infection.
Recommend symptomatic care with calamine lotion and analgesics, as it is too late for antiviral therapy to be effective.

Initiate oral antiviral therapy, such as valacyclovir 1000 mg three times daily for 7 days, and provide counselling on neuropathic pain management, which may include agents like gabapentin or pregabalin.
Administer a single dose of intramuscular corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and pain.

questions.question: The patient is concerned about spreading the rash to her young grandchildren. What is the most accurate advice the Nurse Practitioner should provide regarding the contagiousness of herpes zoster? This counselling is essential to prevent transmission of the varicella-zoster virus.

options.description: Inform her that she is not contagious at all, as shingles is a reactivation of an old virus and cannot be spread.
Explain that she can transmit shingles to others through respiratory droplets, so she should wear a mask around her grandchildren.

Advise her that she can transmit the varicella-zoster virus (which causes chickenpox in non-immune individuals) through direct contact with the fluid from her blisters. She should keep the rash covered and avoid contact with people who have not had chickenpox or the vaccine until the lesions have crusted over.
Reassure her that as long as her grandchildren have received their routine immunizations, they are completely protected and no precautions are necessary.

questions.subdomain: Transition of Care / Discharge Planning / Documentation
questions.question: After the acute episode resolves, the patient asks if she can do anything to prevent another recurrence. What is the most appropriate recommendation the Nurse Practitioner should make and document as part of her long-term care plan? This is a key secondary prevention strategy.

options.description: Recommend she take a low dose of oral acyclovir daily for the rest of her life as prophylaxis.
Advise her to get the recombinant zoster vaccine (Shingrix) once the acute illness has resolved, as it is recommended for adults over 50, even if they have had a previous episode of shingles.
Explain that there is nothing that can be done to prevent future episodes of shingles.
Suggest she get the live zoster vaccine (Zostavax II) as it is more effective in older adults.

questions.reference: National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) Guidelines

case_scenario: A 68-year-old male with a known 10-year history of COPD presents to the primary care clinic with a 3-day history of worsening dyspnea, increased cough, and a change in sputum from its usual white colour to yellow-green. He reports feeling more fatigued and wheezy than usual, requiring his salbutamol inhaler 6-7 times a day, up from his baseline of 2-3 times. He has a 45-pack-year smoking history and continues to smoke a half-pack per day. On examination, his oxygen saturation is 90% on room air, respiratory rate is 24 breaths/min, and he has diffuse expiratory wheezes bilaterally.

questions.question: Upon reviewing the patient's presentation and vital signs, the Nurse Practitioner must prioritize their next assessment action to address the most immediate life-threatening risk. Considering the patient's oxygen saturation of 90%, increased work of breathing, and history of COPD, which of the following actions is the most critical to perform next to evaluate the severity of the exacerbation and guide immediate intervention?

options.description: Order a chest X-ray to rule out pneumonia or pneumothorax.
Perform a detailed medication reconciliation, focusing on his inhaler technique.
Administer a dose of nebulized salbutamol and ipratropium immediately.
Conduct an Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) analysis to assess for hypercapnia and acidosis.

questions.question: The Nurse Practitioner is preparing to order initial diagnostic investigations for this patient. To comprehensively assess for common triggers and complications of a COPD exacerbation while adhering to principles of resource stewardship, which set of investigations is most appropriate to order at this time based on the patient's presenting signs and symptoms?

options.description: Spirometry to confirm the severity of airflow limitation and a D-dimer to rule out pulmonary embolism.
A chest X-ray, complete blood count (CBC) with differential, and a sputum sample for culture and sensitivity.
An electrocardiogram (ECG) and serum electrolytes only, as cardiac comorbidities are common.
A comprehensive metabolic panel, C-reactive protein (CRP), and procalcitonin to gauge inflammation.

questions.question: After integrating the patient's history of worsening dyspnea, increased sputum purulence, the physical exam finding of wheezing, and the initial oxygen saturation of 90%, the Nurse Practitioner formulates a differential diagnosis. Based on the classic presentation triad (Anthonisen criteria), what is the most likely diagnosis that accounts for the patient's complete clinical picture?

options.description: Acute community-acquired pneumonia, given the change in sputum colour and fatigue.
An acute exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD), moderate to severe, with evidence of bacterial involvement.
Decompensated congestive heart failure, as dyspnea and wheezing (cardiac asthma) are present.
Acute pulmonary embolism, given the sudden increase in dyspnea and hypoxemia.

questions.question: The Nurse Practitioner has diagnosed a moderate AECOPD and is creating a management plan for the clinic setting while arranging for transfer to a higher level of care if needed. According to the Canadian Thoracic Society (CTS) guidelines, which combination of pharmacological interventions should be initiated immediately to stabilize the patient by targeting airway inflammation and bronchoconstriction?

options.description: Intravenous methylprednisolone and a long-acting muscarinic antagonist (LAMA) via discus inhaler.
Oral prednisone 40mg daily for 5 days and regularly scheduled nebulized salbutamol/ipratropium.
Initiation of azithromycin for its anti-inflammatory properties and an increase in his maintenance LABA/LAMA inhaler frequency.
A single dose of intramuscular dexamethasone and providing a prescription for a 5-day course of moxifloxacin.

questions.question: Assuming the patient is stabilized and will be managed as an outpatient with close follow-up, the Nurse Practitioner must provide counselling to prevent future exacerbations. Which counselling approach is most effective and comprehensive for this patient, addressing the key modifiable risk factor and ensuring correct self-management?

options.description: Primarily focusing on providing a pamphlet about the benefits of quitting smoking and scheduling a follow-up in one month.
Advising the patient to switch to vaping instead of smoking cigarettes, as it is a less harmful alternative for COPD.

Utilizing the '5 A's' model (Ask, Advise, Assess, Assist, Arrange) for smoking cessation, discussing pharmacotherapy options like varenicline, and performing a teach-back demonstration of his prescribed inhaler technique.
Strongly recommending an immediate and complete cessation of smoking without pharmacological support, as willpower is the most important factor in quitting.

case_scenario: A 52-year-old woman with a 5-year history of Type 2 Diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia presents for her scheduled quarterly follow-up. Her current medications include metformin 1000mg BID, ramipril 10mg daily, and atorvastatin 20mg daily. She reports good adherence but mentions increasing fatigue and a new 'pins and needles' sensation in her feet over the past few months. Her latest lab results show an HbA1c of 8.4%. She expresses concern over the cost of medications as her drug plan at work recently changed.

questions.question: The patient's presentation includes an elevated HbA1c despite reported adherence to metformin and a new sensory complaint. To properly stage her diabetes and screen for prevalent complications, which focused physical assessment is most crucial for the Nurse Practitioner to perform during this visit?

options.description: A comprehensive cardiovascular exam including carotid bruit assessment and ankle-brachial index (ABI) measurement.
A thyroid gland palpation and assessment for signs of hypothyroidism, as fatigue is a primary complaint.
A comprehensive diabetic foot exam, including a 10-g monofilament test, vibration sensation, and inspection for skin integrity.
Measurement of waist circumference and calculation of BMI to re-evaluate her obesity status.

questions.question: In integrating the patient's history, lab results (HbA1c 8.4%), and new neurological symptoms, the Nurse Practitioner recognizes the need to synthesize information beyond glycemic control. Which piece of historical information is most critical to elicit now to fully understand the patient's biopsychosocial context and its impact on her ability to manage her condition?

options.description: A detailed 24-hour dietary recall to assess for specific sources of carbohydrate intake.
Specific details about the changes to her workplace drug coverage, including co-payment amounts and formulary restrictions.
A family history of diabetic complications, particularly nephropathy and retinopathy.
Her typical weekly exercise routine, including the type, duration, and frequency of physical activity.

questions.question: Based on the patient's report of a 'pins and needles' sensation in her feet, coupled with her 5-year history of diabetes and current suboptimal glycemic control (HbA1c 8.4%), the Nurse Practitioner must formulate a working diagnosis for this new symptom. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.description: Vitamin B12 deficiency neuropathy, potentially related to long-term metformin use.
Diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN), a common microvascular complication of diabetes.
Tarsal tunnel syndrome, given the localization of symptoms to the feet.
Restless leg syndrome, which can present with unusual sensations in the lower extremities.

questions.question: The patient's HbA1c is 8.4% on metformin monotherapy, indicating a need for treatment intensification. Given her comorbidities of hypertension and dyslipidemia, but no history of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease or heart failure, and her stated concern about cost, which of the following medication adjustments represents the most appropriate evidence-based and client-centered choice according to the 2023 Diabetes Canada guidelines?

options.description: Add an SGLT2 inhibitor, such as empagliflozin, for its cardiovascular benefits, despite the higher cost.
Add a DPP-4 inhibitor, such as sitagliptin, as it is weight-neutral, has a low risk of hypoglycemia, and is often available in a cost-effective combination tablet with metformin.
Add basal insulin (e.g., glargine U-100) as the next step, as it is the most potent agent for lowering HbA1c.
Add a sulfonylurea, such as glyburide, as it is inexpensive and effective at lowering blood glucose, despite its risks of hypoglycemia and weight gain.

questions.question: After deciding to add a DPP-4 inhibitor to her regimen, the Nurse Practitioner provides counselling. In addition to discussing the medication's mechanism, benefits, and potential side effects, which counselling point is most crucial to include regarding self-monitoring and management?

options.description: Instructing her to begin checking her blood glucose four times a day, including before each meal and at bedtime.
Advising her on the importance of sick day management, including when to check for ketones and how to stay hydrated, especially since her glycemic control is poor.
Recommending she immediately stop taking metformin once she starts the new medication to avoid drug interactions.
Focusing the discussion solely on the low risk of hypoglycemia with the new drug, without discussing other aspects of self-care.

case_scenario: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother with concerns about a persistent, non-productive cough that is worse at night and has been ongoing for the past six weeks. She notes that the cough is often triggered by running and playing with friends. The child had two similar episodes of prolonged coughing following viral colds over the past year. He has a history of eczema as an infant. There is a family history of allergies, with his father having allergic rhinitis. On exam, the child is in no distress, his chest is clear on auscultation at rest, and his oxygen saturation is 99% on room air.

questions.question: The Nurse Practitioner is considering a diagnosis of asthma. Given that the physical exam is unremarkable at rest, which is the most appropriate next step in the assessment process to gather objective evidence for variable expiratory airflow limitation, as recommended by the GINA guidelines for this age group?

options.description: Order a chest X-ray to rule out any structural abnormalities of the lung.
Prescribe a 2-week trial of a daily inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) and assess for clinical response at follow-up.
Refer the child to a pediatric respirologist for a methacholine challenge test.
Perform in-office pre- and post-bronchodilator spirometry to assess for reversibility (an increase in FEV1 of >12%).

questions.question: To formulate a comprehensive understanding of the child's condition, the Nurse Practitioner must synthesize information beyond the chief complaint of coughing. Which line of questioning is most critical to evaluate the potential severity and impact of the suspected asthma on the child's life, aligning with the core principles of a holistic pediatric assessment?

options.description: Inquiring about the child's academic performance and his relationship with his teachers at school.
Asking the mother for a detailed list of all foods the child has eaten in the past week to screen for food allergies.
Investigating the frequency of daytime symptoms, nighttime awakenings due to cough, limitations on activity (e.g., sports), and the frequency of reliever medication use if any has been prescribed.
Focusing on the vaccination history of the child, including whether he has received the annual influenza vaccine.

questions.question: The Nurse Practitioner integrates the findings: a history of recurrent episodic cough worse at night and with exercise, a personal history of atopy (eczema), and a positive family history. The spirometry shows a 15% improvement in FEV1 after salbutamol administration. Based on this constellation of evidence, what is the most definitive diagnosis?

options.description: Allergic rhinitis with post-nasal drip causing a chronic cough.
Mild, persistent asthma.
Recurrent viral bronchitis due to frequent exposure in a school setting.
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) causing nocturnal cough.

questions.question: Having diagnosed mild persistent asthma, the Nurse Practitioner must initiate treatment. According to the GINA guidelines for a 7-year-old child, what is the most appropriate initial management plan to gain symptom control and reduce future risk?

options.description: Prescribe as-needed salbutamol inhaler only, to be used whenever the child feels symptomatic.
Prescribe a daily low-dose inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) plus an as-needed short-acting beta2-agonist (SABA).
Prescribe a daily oral leukotriene receptor antagonist (e.g., montelukast) as a first-line controller therapy.
Prescribe a combination low-dose inhaled corticosteroid/long-acting beta2-agonist (ICS/LABA) inhaler for daily use.

questions.question: The Nurse Practitioner provides the prescriptions and begins to counsel the mother. The mother states, 'I'm worried about him using a steroid every day. Are there any other options?' Which response by the NP best addresses the mother's concern while providing essential education on the therapeutic plan?

options.description: 'The steroid is the only thing that works, and he must take it daily or his asthma will get much worse. The side effects are not that significant.'

'I understand your concern. The low dose of inhaled steroid is very safe and targets the inflammation in his lungs directly, which is the root cause of his cough. This prevents attacks and is much safer than the risks of uncontrolled asthma or needing oral steroids. Let's talk about the specific side effects and how we can minimize them, like using a spacer and rinsing his mouth.'
'We can try an oral medication instead, but it doesn't work as well. It is your choice as a parent to decide which medication you are comfortable with giving to your child.'
'Let's just start with the blue puffer (salbutamol) for now, and if his symptoms don't improve in a few weeks, we will have to add the daily steroid inhaler.'

case_scenario: A 24-year-old female university student presents to the campus wellness clinic with a 2-day history of dysuria, urinary frequency, and suprapubic discomfort. She denies fever, chills, flank pain, or vaginal discharge. She reports being in a monogamous relationship with a new partner for the past two months and uses oral contraceptives for birth control. This is her second such episode in the last six months. A urine dipstick performed at triage is positive for both nitrites and leukocyte esterase. She is otherwise healthy with no known chronic conditions.

questions.question: The patient's history and positive urine dipstick are highly suggestive of an uncomplicated urinary tract infection (UTI). To ensure no complicating factors are missed before proceeding with treatment, which question is most important for the Nurse Practitioner to ask as part of the focused assessment?

options.description: Have you recently travelled outside of Canada?
Is there any possibility you could be pregnant?
What is your average daily fluid intake?
Do you have a family history of kidney stones?

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: UTI in the Adult Female

questions.question: The urine dipstick is positive, and the patient has classic symptoms of a lower UTI with no red flags. In alignment with the principles of antimicrobial stewardship and Choosing Wisely Canada recommendations for a patient with a high pre-test probability of uncomplicated cystitis, what is the Nurse Practitioner's most appropriate next step regarding diagnostic investigations?

options.description: Send the urine for culture and sensitivity testing before initiating any antibiotic treatment.
Order a renal ultrasound to rule out any anatomical abnormalities given the recurrent nature of her infections.
Proceed with empirical treatment based on the clinical presentation and positive dipstick without sending a urine culture.
Order a complete blood count (CBC) to check for leukocytosis as a marker of systemic infection.

questions.question: By integrating the patient's report of dysuria, frequency, and suprapubic pain, the absence of systemic or upper tract symptoms (fever, flank pain), and the positive urine dipstick for nitrites and leukocytes, the Nurse Practitioner can confidently establish the most likely diagnosis. Which diagnosis best fits this clinical picture?

options.description: Acute pyelonephritis.
Urethritis secondary to a sexually transmitted infection.
Acute uncomplicated cystitis.
Interstitial cystitis/painful bladder syndrome.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: UTI in the Adult Female

questions.question: The Nurse Practitioner is selecting an appropriate antibiotic for this patient's second episode of uncomplicated cystitis in six months. Considering the need for effective treatment while minimizing the risk of promoting antibiotic resistance, which is the most appropriate first-line empirical antibiotic choice according to current Canadian guidelines for uncomplicated cystitis in this population?

options.description: A 7-day course of ciprofloxacin, as it has broad-spectrum coverage against urinary pathogens.
A 5-day course of nitrofurantoin, as it achieves high urinary concentration with low systemic effects and resistance rates for E. coli remain low.
A 7-day course of amoxicillin-clavulanate, as it is a commonly used and generally well-tolerated antibiotic.
A single dose of fosfomycin, although its efficacy can be slightly lower than other first-line agents.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: UTI in the Adult Female

questions.question: After prescribing the antibiotic, the Nurse Practitioner counsels the patient on managing her symptoms and preventing future infections. Which piece of advice is the most evidence-based and appropriate to include in this counselling session?

options.description: Recommending daily cranberry juice or cranberry extract tablets, as this is a proven method to prevent UTI recurrence.
Advising her to ensure she voids immediately after sexual intercourse, increasing her daily water intake, and completing the full course of antibiotics even if symptoms resolve early.
Suggesting she and her partner should both be treated with antibiotics to prevent passing the infection back and forth.
Instructing her to stop her oral contraceptive pill, as it is a known major risk factor for developing recurrent urinary tract infections.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: UTI in the Adult Female

case_scenario: A 72-year-old man presents to your primary care clinic with a 3-day history of a painful, burning rash on the right side of his chest that follows a single dermatome. He describes the pain as a constant 7/10. He has a history of osteoarthritis and hypertension, managed with acetaminophen and ramipril. On examination, you note a unilateral band of erythematous papules and vesicles on an erythematous base, extending from his mid-back around to his sternum. He denies any eye symptoms. He is scheduled to visit his newborn grandchild in two days.

questions.question: The patient's clinical presentation is highly suggestive of herpes zoster. Given his plan to visit a newborn, which aspect of his history is most critical for the Nurse Practitioner to elicit to assess the risk of transmission and guide immediate public health counselling?

options.description: His vaccination history, specifically whether he has received the recombinant zoster vaccine (Shingrix).
The vaccination status of the newborn's mother, particularly regarding her varicella immunity during pregnancy.
Whether any of the vesicles have crusted over, as this indicates a significant decrease in viral shedding and infectivity.
A detailed history of his hypertension management to ensure his blood pressure is stable under the stress of the pain.

questions.clinical_context: Older Adult, Infectious Disease/Dermatology, Primary Care

questions.question: The diagnosis of herpes zoster in this case is primarily clinical. However, the Nurse Practitioner must rule out any urgent complications. Which focused assessment should be prioritized to identify a potential ophthalmic emergency that would necessitate an immediate referral, even though the patient denies specific eye symptoms?

options.description: Palpation of the preauricular lymph nodes to check for signs of regional inflammation.
A careful inspection of the tip and side of the nose for any vesicular lesions (Hutchinson's sign).
A cranial nerve exam focusing on CN VII to rule out facial palsy associated with Ramsay Hunt syndrome.
Assessment of the oral mucosa for any enanthem that might suggest disseminated disease.

questions.clinical_context: Older Adult, Infectious Disease/Dermatology, Primary Care

questions.question: To effectively manage this patient's acute herpes zoster and minimize the risk of post-herpetic neuralgia, the Nurse Practitioner must initiate treatment promptly. Based on Canadian guidelines for an immunocompetent adult presenting within 72 hours of rash onset, what is the most appropriate pharmacological management plan?

options.description: Prescribe valacyclovir 1 gram TID for 7 days and a short course of oral prednisone to reduce inflammation.
Prescribe topical acyclovir cream to be applied to the rash five times a day and recommend over-the-counter NSAIDs for pain.
Prescribe amoxicillin 500mg TID for 7 days to prevent secondary bacterial infection of the lesions.
Recommend only supportive care with cool compresses and acetaminophen, as the infection is self-limiting.

questions.clinical_context: Older Adult, Infectious Disease/Dermatology, Primary Care

questions.question: The patient is concerned about the severe pain and asks, 'Will this pain ever go away?' He is also anxious about his upcoming visit with his newborn grandchild. How should the Nurse Practitioner best counsel the patient regarding his pain prognosis and the risk of transmission?

options.description: Reassure him that the pain will completely resolve once the rash clears and that he is not contagious to anyone, including babies.
Explain that while the acute pain will improve, there is a significant chance it will become permanent, and he should cancel the visit with his grandchild indefinitely.

Advise him that he cannot visit his grandchild until all lesions have fully crusted over, as he can transmit the varicella virus (chickenpox) to non-immune individuals. Explain that starting antiviral medication can reduce the risk of long-term nerve pain (post-herpetic neuralgia) and discuss multimodal pain management options.
Tell him to wear a thick sweater to cover the rash, which will be sufficient to prevent transmission, and to rely solely on acetaminophen for pain management.

questions.clinical_context: Older Adult, Infectious Disease/Dermatology, Primary Care

questions.subdomain: Transition of Care / Discharge Planning / Documentation
questions.question: Upon completing the visit and providing prescriptions, the Nurse Practitioner must document the encounter thoroughly. Which documentation entry is most crucial for ensuring continuity of care and medicolegal diligence, particularly regarding the patient's acute risk and the counselling provided?

options.description: A note stating 'Patient seen for shingles. Prescription for valacyclovir provided. Follow up in 1 week.'

Documentation of the dermatomal distribution, vesicle stage, absence of Hutchinson's sign, pain score, and a detailed note outlining the counselling provided about the risk of varicella transmission to non-immune contacts (including the newborn grandchild) and instructions to avoid contact until all lesions are crusted.
A record focusing solely on the patient's pain score and the plan to manage it with analgesics, with a follow-up appointment scheduled for pain reassessment.
A brief entry confirming the diagnosis and noting that the patient was advised to get the shingles vaccine after the acute episode resolves.

questions.clinical_context: Older Adult, Infectious Disease/Dermatology, Primary Care

case_scenario: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents for concerns about his behaviour and school performance. His Grade 3 teacher reported that he is frequently 'in his own world,' fails to complete assignments, is disorganized, and often loses his belongings. At home, his parents note he has extreme difficulty staying on task during homework, is constantly fidgeting, and often interrupts others' conversations. These behaviours have been present since Grade 1 but are now causing significant academic and social challenges. The parents completed the SNAP-IV rating scale prior to the appointment, which showed significant scores in the inattentive and hyperactive/impulsive domains.

questions.question: The parents have provided completed SNAP-IV forms from both home and school. To conduct a comprehensive and sensitive assessment for Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), what is the Nurse Practitioner's most crucial next step to gather integrated, multi-source information and rule out other contributing factors?

options.description: Order a full neuropsychological evaluation for the child, as this is required before any diagnosis can be made.

Conduct separate, confidential interviews with the child and his parents to explore the nature of the symptoms, their onset, duration, and the extent of functional impairment across different settings (home, school, social). Inquire about developmental history, family stressors, and screen for co-existing conditions like anxiety or learning disorders.
Rely solely on the SNAP-IV scores to confirm the diagnosis and move directly to discussing treatment options.
Request a direct phone call with the teacher to discuss only the child's academic failures in the classroom.

questions.question: During the assessment, the parents express frustration and worry. To ensure a holistic evaluation that considers the child's overall well-being and identifies potential comorbidities, which screening tool or assessment is most appropriate for the Nurse Practitioner to incorporate into this visit?

options.description: Administer a growth chart assessment to track height and weight percentiles.
Perform a detailed hearing and vision screening to rule out sensory deficits that could mimic inattention.
Use a standardized tool to screen for co-occurring anxiety and depression, such as the Screen for Child Anxiety Related Disorders (SCARED).
Request a 24-hour dietary recall focusing on sugar and caffeine intake.

questions.question: After a comprehensive assessment, the NP diagnoses ADHD, combined presentation. As this is a 'C' condition (consultation required), the NP discusses the case with a consulting physician who agrees with the diagnosis and management plan. What is the most appropriate first-line, evidence-based management plan to present to the family, encompassing both pharmacological and non-pharmacological strategies?

options.description: Recommend behavioural parent training and classroom accommodations as the sole initial intervention, delaying medication for at least six months.

Initiate treatment with a long-acting stimulant medication (e.g., methylphenidate OROS) and concurrently refer the family to psychoeducation resources and recommend behavioural interventions, such as creating structured routines and providing positive reinforcement.
Prescribe a short-acting stimulant to be taken only on school days during homework time.
Refer the child for individual psychotherapy as the primary treatment modality for ADHD.

questions.question: When discussing the initiation of stimulant medication, the parents state, 'We've heard these drugs can change his personality and stunt his growth. We are very hesitant.' Which counselling response by the Nurse Practitioner best addresses these specific concerns using an evidence-informed and collaborative approach?

options.description: Dismiss their concerns by stating that side effects are rare and that the medication is necessary for him to succeed in school.

Acknowledge their concerns as valid and common. Explain that the goal of medication is to help him focus, not change who he is. Discuss the common side effects, such as decreased appetite, and the plan to monitor his height and weight regularly at each follow-up visit. Frame it as a therapeutic trial that can be adjusted or stopped if needed.
Suggest they try an herbal supplement first before considering prescription medication.
Inform them that without medication, their son will likely fail his grade, putting pressure on them to consent to the treatment plan.

questions.subdomain: Transition of Care / Discharge Planning / Documentation
questions.question: To ensure effective collaboration and support for the child, the Nurse Practitioner needs to facilitate communication with the school. What is the most appropriate action to take regarding the transition and coordination of care with the educational system?

options.description: Write a prescription for the medication and tell the parents to inform the school about the new treatment.
Telephone the child's teacher directly to discuss the diagnosis and medication plan without parental consent, as it is a medical necessity.

With signed parental consent, provide a formal letter to the school outlining the diagnosis, explaining the potential benefits and side effects of the medication, and recommending specific classroom accommodations (e.g., preferential seating, breaking down assignments). Offer to be a point of contact for the school's support team.
Leave all communication and advocacy with the school entirely up to the parents.

case_scenario: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 3-month history of progressive fatigue, generalized weakness, and shortness of breath on exertion. She reports feeling lightheaded occasionally and has noticed that her fingernails are brittle and spoon-shaped. She mentions having unusually heavy menstrual periods for the past year and follows a vegetarian diet. On examination, she has pale conjunctiva and nail beds. Her heart rate is 105 bpm, and her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg.

questions.question: The patient's history and physical findings strongly suggest anemia. To confirm the diagnosis and, more importantly, to differentiate the most likely underlying cause given her specific risk factors (heavy menses, vegetarian diet), which set of initial laboratory investigations should the Nurse Practitioner prioritize?

options.description: A complete blood count (CBC) with differential, serum ferritin, and a thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level.
Only a hemoglobin and hematocrit level to confirm the presence of anemia.
Serum vitamin B12 and folate levels, as vegetarian diets are a primary risk factor for these deficiencies.
An electrocardiogram (ECG) to investigate her tachycardia and a basic metabolic panel.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Iron Deficiency Anemia

questions.question: In analyzing the patient's symptoms of fatigue, exertional dyspnea, and tachycardia, the Nurse Practitioner must consider the broader systemic impact. Which part of the physical examination is most crucial to perform to assess for signs of high-output heart failure, a potential complication of severe, chronic anemia?

options.description: A thorough abdominal exam focusing on palpating for splenomegaly.
A neurological exam, including assessment of proprioception and vibration sense.
A cardiovascular assessment, specifically auscultating for a systolic flow murmur, checking for peripheral edema, and assessing the jugular venous pressure (JVP).
A detailed skin examination to look for jaundice or petechiae.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Iron Deficiency Anemia

questions.question: Lab results return showing: Hb 92 g/L, MCV 72 fL, and a ferritin of 5 µg/L, confirming iron deficiency anemia. The NP's management plan must address both the iron deficiency and the underlying cause. Which management plan is most comprehensive and appropriate for this patient?

options.description: Recommend she increase her intake of dietary iron and recheck her labs in 3 months.

Prescribe oral ferrous sulfate 325 mg TID and advise her to take it with a full glass of orange juice on an empty stomach. Also, initiate a referral to gynecology for assessment and management of her menorrhagia.
Arrange for an intravenous iron infusion as first-line treatment and suggest she start eating red meat.
Prescribe a daily multivitamin with iron and schedule a follow-up appointment in 6 months.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Iron Deficiency Anemia

questions.question: When counselling the patient about starting oral iron therapy, the Nurse Practitioner must anticipate common challenges to adherence. What is the most important information to provide the patient to manage common side effects and optimize absorption?

options.description: Warn her that oral iron often causes significant gastrointestinal upset, like constipation and nausea, and suggest she can take it with meals if needed, although this may slightly reduce absorption. Also, inform her that her stools will turn black, which is a normal and expected effect.
Instruct her to take the iron supplement with a calcium tablet or a glass of milk to prevent stomach upset.
Advise her to only take the iron supplement on days she feels particularly fatigued to minimize side effects.
Inform her that results are immediate and she should feel better within a few days of starting the supplement.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Iron Deficiency Anemia

questions.subdomain: Transition of Care / Discharge Planning / Documentation
questions.question: After initiating treatment and providing counselling, the Nurse Practitioner plans for follow-up. What is the most appropriate timeline and plan for monitoring the patient's response to oral iron therapy to ensure efficacy and safe continuation of care?

options.description: No follow-up labs are needed; the patient should return only if her symptoms do not improve.
Repeat the CBC and ferritin level in 2 weeks to see the maximal effect of the treatment.

Schedule a follow-up appointment in 4-6 weeks to repeat the CBC to check for an appropriate rise in hemoglobin, and then again at 3-4 months to ensure ferritin stores are repleted. Reinforce the plan to investigate the underlying cause of her blood loss.
Plan to repeat the CBC in 6 months, as it takes a long time for iron stores to replete.

questions.reference: BC Clinical Practice Guidelines: Iron Deficiency Anemia

case_scenario: A 68-year-old man presents for his annual physical. He has well-controlled hypertension but reports a new and bothersome onset of urinary symptoms over the past six months, including hesitancy, a weak stream, and a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. He also mentions waking up 3-4 times per night to urinate (nocturia). He denies any dysuria, hematuria, or fever. He completes an International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS) questionnaire in the clinic, and his score is 18, indicating moderate symptoms.

questions.question: The patient's symptoms are highly suggestive of lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) secondary to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). To complete a thorough initial assessment and rule out other potential causes, including malignancy, which physical examination is essential for the Nurse Practitioner to perform?

options.description: A focused abdominal examination to palpate for a distended bladder.
A digital rectal examination (DRE) to assess the size, consistency, and contour of the prostate gland and to screen for nodules or induration.
A neurological assessment of the lower extremities to rule out a spinal pathology causing urinary retention.
An assessment of the patient's gait and mobility to see if he can access the toilet easily at night.

questions.question: In addition to the physical exam, the Nurse Practitioner is considering laboratory investigations. Following the principles of Choosing Wisely Canada regarding routine PSA screening, and based on this patient's presentation with moderate LUTS, what is the most appropriate action regarding Prostate-Specific Antigen (PSA) testing?

options.description: Immediately order a PSA test, as it is a required part of the workup for any patient with urinary symptoms.

Engage in a shared decision-making conversation with the patient, discussing the potential benefits (early cancer detection) and harms (over-diagnosis, biopsies) of PSA testing before ordering the test based on his preference and risk factors.
Do not order a PSA test, as his symptoms are clearly from BPH and the test is not recommended.
Order a urinalysis first, and only order the PSA if there is evidence of hematuria.

questions.question: The DRE reveals a moderately enlarged, smooth, firm prostate, and the patient decides to proceed with medical management for his moderate BPH symptoms after a shared decision-making discussion. Which pharmacological agent is the most appropriate first-line treatment to offer this patient to improve his urinary flow and reduce symptoms?

options.description: A 5-alpha-reductase inhibitor, such as finasteride, to shrink the prostate gland.
An anticholinergic agent, such as oxybutynin, to help with bladder storage symptoms.
An alpha-1-adrenergic antagonist, such as tamsulosin, which relaxes the smooth muscle in the bladder neck and prostate.
A loop diuretic, such as furosemide, to be taken in the afternoon to reduce nocturia.

questions.question: When prescribing tamsulosin, the Nurse Practitioner must counsel the patient on potential side effects and specific administration instructions. Which of the following counselling points is most critical to provide to ensure patient safety?

options.description: Advise the patient that the medication can cause erectile dysfunction and he should report this immediately.
Inform him about the risk of first-dose hypotension and dizziness, and advise him to take the first dose at bedtime. Also, caution him to rise slowly from a sitting or lying position.
Tell him to take the medication with a large meal to enhance its absorption and effectiveness.
Explain that the medication may turn his urine a different colour, which is a harmless side effect.

questions.subdomain: Transition of Care / Discharge Planning / Documentation
questions.question: The patient is started on tamsulosin. To ensure appropriate and safe follow-up, which plan for transition and continued monitoring should the Nurse Practitioner document and communicate to the patient?

options.description: Schedule a follow-up appointment in 6 months to see if symptoms have improved, with no other monitoring needed.

Book a follow-up visit in 4-8 weeks to assess for therapeutic effect (improvement in IPSS) and to monitor for side effects, particularly postural hypotension. Plan for an annual follow-up thereafter if stable.
Provide a referral to a urologist immediately for surgical consideration, as medical management often fails.
Give the patient a 1-year prescription and ask him to return for a follow-up only if his symptoms worsen significantly.
